reviews.text: The latest in the superhero franchise is not without its pleasures, but is mostly a strange, headache inducing mess.
reviews.author: Christina Newland

reviews.text: In Quantumania, Newton’s Cassie has so much heart, and it makes it so easy to root for her
reviews.author: Branyan Towe

reviews.text: It isn’t bad per se, but it feels undercooked. By trying to do too much in one outing, it ultimately ends up doing little at all.
reviews.author: Calum Cooper

reviews.text: Scott Lang, aka Ant-Man, is no hero.
reviews.author: Joshua Polanski

reviews.text: Not everything about the film works. For the first time in a while this does feel like a lot of set up instead of a satisfying film.
reviews.author: Paul Klein

reviews.text: An essential film to understand the future of the MCU. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Andrea Zamora

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a film that also manages to balance VFX spectacle and groundedness in its third act. And although the conclusion feels slightly rushed, the ending is better than that of many MCU films we’ve seen lately.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Peterson

reviews.text: It may feel like the director ordered a truckload of kitchen sinks to throw into this chaotic, complicated-yet-dumb, serious-yet-silly, imperfect extravaganza, but he still manages to serve up an astonishing tale.
reviews.author: Lee Zumpe

reviews.text: While I still like the film overall. Every MCU movie now just becoming setup for the next is making characters like Ant-Man lose some of their charm.
reviews.author: Cris Parker

reviews.text: the two-dimensional supporting characters and bloated, derivative universe-building feel like pink filler for too long before flashbacks reveal Janet and Kang’s time together and give us some pique of interest.
reviews.author: Sarah Vincent

reviews.text: The errors are easy to miss because the script and all of the acting performances are drenched in a goop of CGI characters that obliterate everything in their path.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: Excessive, repetitive, unnecessary dialogue driven by exposition, along with a lack of stronger tonal balance and an underdeveloped narrative devoid of true stakes - character arcs are almost non-existent - make this an overall very inconsistent watch.
reviews.author: Manuel São Bento

reviews.text: This is yet another Marvel movie where the tired trope makes its way into driving the plot: A character does something foolish which creates havoc for their world while most of the original cast is separated from one another the bulk of the time.
reviews.author: Matthew Creith

reviews.text: For most of its run-time, it feels like a filler episode of an anime, with only its climax operating as a narrative “threshold”.
reviews.author: Hector A. Gonzalez

reviews.text:
Ant Man And The Wasp Quantumania  The film’s first act kicks off as a badass Star Wars Adventure BUT slowly tires out towards the middle. Fun? Absolutely! Exposition heavy? Yes!
A mixed bag overall
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: Marvel isn’t in the business of telling stories. They are in the business of selling action figures. That’s why you have so many characters wearing brand-new but hideous-looking costumes frolicking around to pad the runtime.
reviews.author: Pramit Chatterjee

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a good time.
reviews.author: Brooke Obie

reviews.text: This movie looks bad.
reviews.author: Chris McCoy

reviews.text: Everything about it is phony and flat from the start, visually unappealing and narratively aimless.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: The supposedly limitless storytelling device has been pushed to its narrative limits. Just look to Quantumania for proof.
reviews.author: Charles Holmes

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors as Kang the Conqueror is almost the only great thing about this quasi-animated film that was supposed to bring life to a most expected quantum realm. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Victor Pineyro

reviews.text: Like it or not, this is the ouroboros the Marvel Cinematic Universe has become. Kang's backstory may be a little more convoluted than Thanos's, but in the end he also just wants to "burn the broken worlds" to create a better one.
reviews.author: Pete Vonder Haar

reviews.text: The Marvel Cinematic Universe’s Phase Ho-Hum ended with the release of Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, and Phase Shoulder Shrug kicks off with Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: This feels like a "stepping stone" film that came off like a "Star Wars" rip-off. This didn't move the needle for the MCU or these characters.
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: I wasn't a big fan of this movie and some of the performances. I was surprised with how low the stakes in this story were. Kang was wasted and Michael Pena was greatly missed.
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: While it had some pleasing visuals and some strong performances from Paul Rudd and others Quantumania still managed to fall flat. It’s not a bad film, it’s not a good film, it’s firmly in the extremely mundane middle…
reviews.author: David Hogan

reviews.text: …this film’s action sorely lacks the ingenious charm offered by the super-scale skirmishes seen in the first two Ant-Man films, and the result is incomprehensible gibberish…
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: All you’ll find is another building block of content that will come out quarterly but leave no lasting impression.
reviews.author: Kip Mooney

reviews.text: It's a two-hour-long computer-generated video game that stays afloat because of two things: Rudd's comic timing and Majors' acting clinic.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: Visually, Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania is incredible, with precise details and colors exploding everywhere on screen.
reviews.author: Allison Rose

reviews.text: Be thankful you didn't squander your money at the box-office! This atrocious escapade is one of the most worthless entries in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: Appropriately for the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s tiniest heroes, the charms of “Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania” are small, but still satisfying,
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: The general color-drenched too-muchness of it all might be tolerable if the plot wasn’t such a by-the-numbers slog, alternating hyperkinetic action sequences with draggy recitations of exposition.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: ...this trip into Quantumania is a missed opportunity.
reviews.author: Michael Ward

reviews.text: Most unfortunate of all, the usually reliable Paul Rudd coasts through this one, wearing his charisma like an old shirt that he forgot to wash and iron before putting on, assuming we'd just love seeing it (and him) again.
reviews.author: Nathaniel Rogers

reviews.text: Quantumania has the goods. It lets Majors take new big bad Kang out for a joyride without feeling like he’s just slumming it in an Ant-Man picture.
reviews.author: Eric Webb

reviews.text: The MCU spent Phase 4 showing a sprawling universe at some point, they’re all going to have to come together to beat the crap out of each other. We’ve got a whole multiverse to sit down to, so let Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania be that appetizer.
reviews.author: MontiLee Stormer

reviews.text: I love Marvel and understand the implications the film is supposed to have as it ushers in Phase 5. What I’m at a loss to understand is just why this task was laid at the feet of Ant-Man.
reviews.author: Stacey Yvonne

reviews.text: Because audiences warm to Paul Rudd’s humor, his third stand-alone Ant-Man outing should have gone for the laughs, not some convoluted mythology that explains nothing.
reviews.author: Bruce R. Miller

reviews.text: Far from the best the MCU has to offer but fun, energetic, and quirky enough to overlook its flaws. Also: Jonathan Majors.
reviews.author: Brian Gill

reviews.text: While Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania’s overwhelming onslaught of half baked CGI and hamfisted performances may be the bulk of the film’s over two hour runtime, one performer who isn’t sleepwalking to his payday is Jonathan Majors.
reviews.author: Dan Tabor

reviews.text: A disastrous mess with the Ant population expanding. Even the family gardener has a suit which means Scott Lang’s role is reduced to carrying everybody’s luggage.
reviews.author: Victoria Alexander

reviews.text: You have a great cast that gets lost in an overstuffed story. There's no emotional connections, so many of the characters just didn't get enough screen time, and the goals of what they're setting up with Kang feel too abstract.
reviews.author: Kristen Maldonado

reviews.text: I cannot imagine ranking it anywhere other than dead last out of the 31 features presently constituting the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: Clumsy storytelling and underdeveloped characters unfortunately prevented it from being the spectacular strong start that Phase 5 needed it to be.
reviews.author: Ineye Komonibo

reviews.text: Quantumania is a lifeless, mirthless CGI saturnalia that dispenses almost entirely with the emotional core of its characters. In its place, Peyton Reed and his production team have resorted to the worst sort of empty spectacle filmmaking.
reviews.author: Piers Marchant

reviews.text: The whole thing seems to be built almost entirely on cliches and tropes, with no gravity, no sense of impact or consequence.
reviews.author: Sameen Amer

reviews.text: As a standalone movie, it falls squarely right in the center of worth it and not worth it to see in theaters.
reviews.author: Frantz Jerome

reviews.text: Despite a smattering of jokes, Peyton Reed’s film just isn’t as much fun as the others.
reviews.author: Edward Porter

reviews.text: With very small powers come no real responsibilities.
reviews.author: Jay Horton

reviews.text: Amidst the Kang mythmaking, Reed remembers to make time for Scott and Cassie, giving the film its sweetest moments and the closest it comes to the old Ant-Man heart.
reviews.author: Joel Harley

reviews.text: I liked this film a lot, the fun and the humor are still there, but the stakes are definitively raised.
reviews.author: tt stern-enzi

reviews.text: ... While the film has a bunch of things to pick apart, it's aesthetic and visual enjoyability isn't one of them.
reviews.author: Cris Kennedy

reviews.text: I thought this was fun, entertaining, visually interesting, the characters worked well, and the villain is spot on. Is it amazing? Is it top tier? No, I don't think it was ever going to be. But I don't regret my time with it.
reviews.author: Vera Wylde

reviews.text: [Jonathan Majors] elevated the material and was in a realm altogether... [But the movie] was too drunk on its own mythology.
reviews.author: Lael Loewenstein

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors is just outstanding. He's in a different movie, giving a Shakespearean performance in what is otherwise... well, it's Ant-Man.
reviews.author: Tim Cogshell

reviews.text:
"Ant-Man & The Wasp: Quantumania" is going to be lower on the MCU movie list. But, with its thrilling action sequences and funny one liners, this sequel makes for an enjoyable 
blockbuster that's worth catching on the big screen.
reviews.author: Susan Kamyab

reviews.text:
ANT-MAN & THE WASP: Quantumania feels more like a Disney+ special than a film.

It’s messy, overindulgent on weak CGI, and humor falls flat. Jonathan Majors is great as Kang but Marvel seemed more focused on creating a 2-hour trailer for something better.
reviews.author: Sheraz Farooqi

reviews.text: Quantumania swings big, but forgets the small stuff, to its own detriment.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: A movie about Ant-Man & Wasp would do well to focus on Ant-Man & Wasp.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: In a universe with 20+ films, one of them has to be the worst, and Quantamania is a strong contender for that inauspicious title, lacking any emotional mooring or reason to care whatsoever
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: Ant-Man is for wacky capers and comic relief in Avengers movies, not exposition-heavy narrative centerpieces responsible for setting up the next three years of cinematic storytelling.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: 31 films deep in the MCU means there are bound to be a few duds. The barrage of overblown effects and a story devoid of emotion makes this entry a bottom dweller. The good news, Phase 5 can only get better.
reviews.author: Joe Friar

reviews.text: Anyone who fears that too many blockbusters are becoming too similar won't feel fortunate while watching... The MCU is going massive on Kang, patently; if only it'd kept the Ant-Man pictures small.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: More sci-fi than superhero flick this time, taking cues from Star Wars and gets really fantastical. While it may not be the best in the series, it's a totally fun installment and one that's worth seeing on the big screen.
reviews.author: Paul Salfen

reviews.text: All of this makes the plot feel both murky and corny, while the action is less than convincing. Still, the cast is on fine form, finding moments of emotion alongside the snarky relationship humour.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: A prologue that desperately seeks to make the irrelevant relevant. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Emmanuel Báez

reviews.text: The Quantum Realm is strikingly similar to that other space movie, if not a chintzy reproduction whose heavy CGI work is like lipstick on a space boar.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: I can't remember ever wanting to walk out during a press screening of any post-2008 Marvel movie, but I had the urge this time around and wouldn't have missed much had I followed that impulse.
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania is pure, indulgent escapism that never forgets comic book movies are supposed to be fun.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: The ensuing plot is mostly gibberish, full of universe-threatening stakes that are too easily overcome.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: After three movies, and a couple of Avengers appearances, we finally get a Scott and Cassie movie.
reviews.author: JD Duran

reviews.text: Is it worth watching this to keep up with the MCU? Sure. It's hard not to root for the "little guy." But this movie is "just fine" instead of particularly funny, thrilling, or memorable.
reviews.author: Sandie Angulo Chen

reviews.text: Crawls instead of buzzes.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: The more appealing thing about the whole enterprise is the mental image of these former A-listers hanging out between takes, swapping stories of the old days and competing over who least understands the script.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

reviews.text: By virtue of placing a character that is nearly street level with a universe threatening opponent, you have to make the movie rise to meet it. However Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is largely stuck in needing to be bigger.
reviews.author: Terence Johnson

reviews.text: Portrayed by Jonathan Majors, Kang is an intense menacing presence who gives the MCU the jolt it has sorely needed since Avengers: End Game.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: nt-Man 3 is a fun if predictable superhero movie that gets a few big things wrong, but bounces back on the strength of its leads, with both Paul Rudd and Jonathan Majors knocking it out of the park.
reviews.author: Erik Kain

reviews.text: A return to what Marvel does best ... teasing the next movie.
reviews.author: Kenneth R. Morefield

reviews.text: Rarely has a film about a family in peril been so utterly devoid of suspense. The problem, it seems, is that Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania exists as part of a larger enterprise.
reviews.author: Chris Wasser

reviews.text: One good scene can't fix a film overloaded with so much plot -- and so many characters -- that you'll actually wish everyone slowed down to tell their corny jokes.
reviews.author: Josh Rosenberg

reviews.text: The thrill is gone. The Marvel Universe shoots a blank. A tiny one.
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: The stand-out element is Majors, whose unsettlingly cool, calm and collected performance as Kang will have you eagerly anticipating his next MCU appearance.
reviews.author: Matthew Turner

reviews.text: As another Merry Marvel Continuity Exercise, it could be a lot worse. At least they have a compellingly-acted villain again, even if they aren’t quite sure what to do with him on the way to their destination.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: 'Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania' is the weirdest, most fun movie of the three. Yet, it's bogged down by serving as another stepping stone on the road to Marvel's Multiverse Saga.
reviews.author: Alejandra Martinez

reviews.text: An uneven mix of comedy and action that lacks epicness, but thrives on introducing a dangerous new villain. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rene Sanchez

reviews.text: The film covers no new ground, offers no new concepts. and introduces almost nothing fresh in the way of storytelling or character development. Rudd and Reed made a solid duo in the past, but this time around the formula stands out more than the charm.
reviews.author: Erin Maxwell

reviews.text: It's nice Hollywood's been scouring metaphysical and cosmological texts and translating them into comic book popcorn entertainment (The Quantum Realm!) but the over-usage of CGI as a lazy replacement for the craft of good storytelling is tedious.
reviews.author: Mark Jackson

reviews.text: There are some truly fun pieces to it, some genuinely inventive and impressive visuals, and a mostly likable cast. But it doesn’t do enough to separate itself from the blurred, messy palette that the MCU has become to truly stand out. It’s… fine.
reviews.author: TK Burton

reviews.text: Tentatively pushing into broader fantasy cinema, it retains frissons for those of us who did grow up having our imaginations blown open by Jack Kirby.
reviews.author: Nick Hasted

reviews.text: As far as superhero action movies go, this one works well enough. There is plenty of action and plenty of imaginative eye candy. The acting is good. The soundtrack is also solid. It should prove to be a popular addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: It suffers from some script problems in the first half, but it ultimately delivers a bonkers but exciting gateway to the next Marvel phase.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: The visuals are so busy, the jokes so tame, the homilies so overfamiliar, the only option is surrendering to the chaos. But those pros Pfeiffer and Douglas up the game with an interstellar Romancing the Stone vibe.
reviews.author: Thelma Adams

reviews.text: The lackluster writing and typical Marvel clichés don't allow for Rudd's effortless charm to carry the character.
reviews.author: Courtney Lanning

reviews.text: Thoroughly enjoyed Ant Man And The Wasp: Quantumania. Jonathan Majors is a superstar with Michelle Pfeiffer matching him beat for beat. The world building of the Quantum Realm is stunning. It has the right mix of humor, emotional stakes, action, and awe.
reviews.author: John Rocha

reviews.text: Talent can't hide the fact that the movie gets less and less interesting as it progresses.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: It is good moments overwhelmed by a bloated structure.
reviews.author: Alci Rengifo

reviews.text: While an ant can lift  5,000 times its own body weight, there's little to support here.
reviews.author: Annie Banks

reviews.text: Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania takes you on a fun adventure. And, as always, stay back for Easter eggs in the mid and post credit scenes.
reviews.author: Mihir Bhanage

reviews.text: This film is silly and messy and pretty and trippy, and though it fulfills the obligations of vweepy laser fights, digital everything, and several different varieties of product placement, it’s not going to reshape the marketplace.
reviews.author: Jason Shawhan

reviews.text: One of Marvel's most visually inventive films with fantastical world-building, and the franchise's most imposing villain yet in Kang the Conqueror.
reviews.author: Joseph Garcia

reviews.text: Nearly immediately, director Peyton Reed stomps on the gas, plunging our itsy-bitsy heroes into chases, fistfights, battle sequences and other assorted setpieces.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: You really don't have to do this to yourself. You have the power to walk away.
reviews.author: Bob Grimm

reviews.text: The real badass presence of Jonathan Majors  and Michelle Pfeiffer going toe to toe in the mulitverse will keep audiences on their toes and salivating for more.
reviews.author: Carla Renata

reviews.text: Quantumania maintains the quirky fun of the Ant-Man movies and is a great introduction to Kang but it struggles with massively combating tones. It's solid entertainment but the MCU bag of tricks have become redundant and exhausting.
reviews.author: Cody Leach

reviews.text: “Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania” is a visual exposition filled with childish jokes and underwritten characters. Phase Five has me asking why I should root for the little guy when there’s a titan like Majors portraying Kang.
reviews.author: Rosa Parra

reviews.text: A superhero epic of gargantuan proportions that overwhelms and overstimulates, but still manages to deliver some human emotions despite the CGI circus.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: The overall narrative is pedestrian but offers enough flashes, bangs, and general weirdness for those who prefer to sit back and absorb such things.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: On the whole, Quantamania lacked heart because the actors didn't really have anything to work with, and it felt like Disney/Marvel didn't really care about the film at all.
reviews.author: Gabi Zietsman

reviews.text: "Quantumania" has greater stakes and a grander canvas than the more lighthearted previous chapters of the Ant-Man saga, and the film mostly negotiates the tricky tonal shift -- even if the results are more predictable than spectacular.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: QUANTUMANIA takes the us deep into a micro-verse in this action-adventure space opera, introducing us to a strange new world and bringing a new big bad to the MCU, while reminding us all that it's never too late to stop being a dick.
reviews.author: Patrick Hicks

reviews.text: After an encouraging start, Quantumania succumbs to mediocrity when it had the chance to propel the MCU forward effectively. Jonathan Majors is great, but the movie is anything but.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: A dire and crummy movie, one of the worst ever produced by Marvel.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Part 3 plugs all of it back into Feige and company’s plan, an increasingly bland one. Maybe it’s Marvel fatigue or a simple case of sequelitis, but the magic in these films has ceased to exist.
reviews.author: Dan Buffa

reviews.text: It feels like Marvel is starting to spin its wheels a bit, with this Ant-Man movie a weird blend of refried Guardians of the Galaxy and a far-less interesting extension of what Loki was doing with all the multiverse hubbub.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: That’s what I like about these Marvel films, man. I get older, and they stay the same.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: The film’s main asset is Jonathan Majors as Kang the Conqueror: his performance, with its velvet-soft line deliveries and unfathomable, boundless rage, is the magnetic core of this incoherent effects-dump of a movie.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: Without, apparently, greater airs than entertain and offer a different experience within the recen moth-eaten offer of Marvel Studios, 'Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania' sets a fantastic start for the Phase 5.
reviews.author: Víctor López G.

reviews.text:
There is a universe out there where Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a good movie.
It ain't this one.
reviews.author: Adam Olinger

reviews.text: Undermined like too many recent MCU entries by murky, muddy visuals ... an under-motivated, underdeveloped super-villain, a script light on humour and long on family drama, [the film] at least benefits from an unsurprisingly strong cast
reviews.author: Mel Valentin

reviews.text: Nothing more than a desperate money grab for Marvel, overplaying an already weak minor character, to bide time for the next phase.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors is great but his Kang—the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s next big bad—suffers in a film that looks fake and struggles to sketch an arc for its growing ensemble.
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: Despite strong performances from the cast, 'Quantumania' is dull and exhausting to sit through. Marvel’s glory days might be behind us and I’m really not looking forward to the rest of Phase Five.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: And yet, there it was, that thought, overarching and overwhelming: “I didn’t feel a thing.”
reviews.author: Matthew Lickona

reviews.text: Ant-Man’s return is notable for the villain and not a lot more, meaning this sequel shrinks into the back of the memory rather quickly, disappearing into the multiversal content void almost as if it never existed in the first place.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: Despite an uneven tone, Quantumania mostly works as an enticing superhero adventure, despite how hard it veers away from Ant-Man’s previously zippy nature.
reviews.author: Mark McPherson

reviews.text: Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania may be lacking in any discernible drama or emotional stakes but it is easily one of the most solidly entertaining and spectacular of Marvel’s ‘Phase 4’ run of of film and TV.
reviews.author: Christopher Machell

reviews.text: It’s a troubling thing for a franchise to be this much at an impasse when everyone involved insists, fingers apparently crossed behind their backs, that they’re finally forging ahead.
reviews.author: David Lynch

reviews.text: The world is an amazing spectacle, but the writing feels 20 years old.
reviews.author: Doug Walker

reviews.text: To be sure, this isn’t first-rate Marvel, but it’s better than most of the Phase Four entries.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Gloriously weird.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: Overall it’s another lackluster blockbuster.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: Despite a nice family dynamic between the Langs and Pyms, the lack of clarity around new villain Kang and the subpar visual effects make the film a lackluster addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.author: Nicole Ackman

reviews.text: ANT-MAN AND THE WASP: QUANTUMANIA leaves some unanswered questions, and its action scenes rely more on fisticuffs than clever size-shifting props and fight choreography. It’s still a fun outing with likable characters, just not a fantastic voyage.
reviews.author: Valerie Kalfrin

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania opens up another new, wonderfully weird avenue for adventures in the MCU, but the film’s ambition occasionally outpaces an otherwise fun cast and the intriguing concepts it teases.
reviews.author: Rick Marshall

reviews.text: A solid film that happens to have Ant-Man and The Wasp in it as opposed to being a good Ant-Man and The Wasp film, but it does provide a course correct of sorts while providing needed focus to the saga’s ultimate threat.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a solid mid-tier MCU entry. One simply wishes that the film didn’t exist principally to set-up the villain/conflict for the rest of the Phase 5. Did we really need a two hour film just to introduce Kang?
reviews.author: Joe Lipsett

reviews.text: The visuals, however derivative, are elegant, witty and well-executed, and the glamorous cast is in pleasant form. Rudd's sly, subtle clowning is always good company, and he carries the movie effortlessly.
reviews.author: M.V. Moorhead

reviews.text: Another drab apocalypse, but with charming fellow passengers to pass the time in charming fashion as noxious clouds swirl, and dim tapestry keeps unfurling in lieu of landscape... the slurry of action is just more Marvel mayhem.
reviews.author: Ray Pride

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp is two hours of the last 20 minutes of most Marvel movies. Even viewers who haven’t experienced MCU fatigue may find themselves feeling it this time.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The latest phase of the MCU begins in the microscopic world of the Quantum Realm - but is Marvel in danger of burnout just as Kang arrives?
reviews.author: Scott Davis

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania, a film that blasts into a galaxy far, far away. While there are plenty of bumps on the journey, it's hard not to be fully invested in Jonathan Majors' magnetic presence and Paul Rudd's contagious charm.
reviews.author: David Gonzalez

reviews.text: Fails to live up to the standard of his first two Ant-Man films.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: The whole film takes place in the green-screen world of the quantum realm; it’s heavy on the visuals with a fairly light, predictable Marvel story.
reviews.author: Josh Flanders

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors' villain Kang saves the film and Paul Rudd is watchable as ever.
reviews.author: Suchin Mehrotra

reviews.text: The Ant-Man films have been a palette cleanser for audiences involved in the Marvel Universe. Goofy and amusing stakes often with immediate rather than world-building implications. Trading humor for direness was a major miscalculation.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: The worst Marvel movie yet...
reviews.author: Caryn James

reviews.text: The film is strictly made for die-hard Marvel and Ant-Man fans. Watch it for its special effects and imaginatively constructed landscape and creatures. Don’t go looking for drama and you won’t be disappointed.
reviews.author: Devesh Sharma

reviews.text: Some of the Marvel (and DC) franchises do feel a bit past their use-by date. “It’s never over,” Kang says at one point. He speaks the truth, for better or worse.
reviews.author: Stephen Romei

reviews.text: The MCU has become an emotional Ponzi Scheme. You're expected to watch not because this will make you feel something today, but in the hopes that this continuity will matter somewhere down the line.
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: All the little things that make an ‘Ant-Man’ film so delightful have been stripped from the latest installment in service of the greater Marvel machine...
reviews.author: Miles Surrey

reviews.text: This film is impossible to take seriously, but never makes the mistake of doing so itself, and as a consequence is perfectly watchable.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: The dialogue and the screenplay are some of the worst I've experienced recently from an MCU film. However, once Jonathan Majors's character Kang comes into the play during the third act, things get slightly more interesting.
reviews.author: Tatat Bunnag

reviews.text: It may seem that Quantumania loses some of its soul by serving the multiverse saga set up for the MCU, which we saw happen with Iron Man 2. However, the film is still a great one-time, big-screen watch...
reviews.author: Aniruddho Chakraborty

reviews.text: This is the film that's supposed to usher in the next phase in the Marvel Universe? It's a weak attempt to establish Kang the Conquerer (Jonathan Majors) as the next super villain of Thanos-sized proportions. Kang (and Majors) deserve a better launch.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: While the story isn’t as compelling as it could be, thanks in part to some choppiness of the narrative, the overall arcs are engaging and this really sets up a villain who’s a powerful threat.
reviews.author: Chris Joyce

reviews.text: Nothing in “Quantumania” is outright bad. I’d watch it a hundred thousand times before watching “Avatar 2” ever again. Nobody tell James Cameron I said that. He’s got “Make that guy disappear” money for sure now...
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: I’m getting bored just typing all this up. More concerningly, it looks like the filmmakers themselves were bored putting it onscreen.
reviews.author: Bilge Ebiri

reviews.text: Quantumania triumphs in its presentation of the new villain of the saga. Not only is Kang's character menacing, but his motivations and characteristics are resolved with grace.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Luis Angel H. Mora

reviews.text: Go in just expecting an enjoyable film that the family can laugh along with and you’re sure to leave fulfilled.
reviews.author: Theolin Tembo

reviews.text: Imagine a Roger Corman film made with the combined budgets of every Roger Corman film and you are halfway there.
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: [A] good, entertaining, visually splendid sci-fantasy movie willing to take its premise and leads in a new direction.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: This is the Marvel way: The studio recruits actors and directors for their distinctive qualities, but over time the thing that stuck out  gets filed down, until they're just part of the machine.  Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is more of the same.
reviews.author: Eli Glasner

reviews.text: A mostly fun journey into the tiny-verse.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: Quantumania represents an embarrassing low point for the MCU, a soulless cash-grab that debases the very idea of cinema itself. A just world would never allow the superhero genre to recover from such an artistically bankrupt abomination.
reviews.author: Ian Thomas Malone

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors is giving an emotionally acrobatic performance that this franchise does not deserve.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: The storytelling's a bit unmoored, but Paul Rudd shines in a colorful cantina of weird alien creatures and Jonathan Majors gives a charismatic pathos to Kang the Conqueror. Isn't it nice to have MCU movies that are just plain fun again?
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: I’d even call it good enough. But it’s just sort of average — which, for Marvel, is decidedly below average.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: Naturally, the special effects in Peyton Reed’s film are dazzling. But there is such a thing as too much dazzle, for which the best-known antidote is to shut your eyes.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: And the film is never complex, only complicated, which is very different. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Javier Ocaña

reviews.text: I returned from the journey to the Quantum Realm feeling less like a satisfied moviegoer than a traveler who had acquired another stamp on my Marvel passport.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: This is another entry that fails to muster excitement or move things forward in a meaningful way. It just exists – a gear in a moneymaking machine that is starting to lose its steam.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: There are some zippy set pieces where our heroes use their size-shifting suits to bat away Kang’s brittle stormtroopers. But the plot is formulaic and the dialogue largely witless... I’ll probably remember this as “the Baskin-Robbins One”.
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: Marvel’s “Rick and Morty”... no longer intended for the casual moviegoer... the MCU demands you keep up... Edited to the bone to avoid Eternals-like running time and over-exposition, Quantumania comes up short in emotion and extreme for spectacle.
reviews.author: Kevin A. Ranson

reviews.text: It’s ‘Quantumania’ not The Who’s ‘Quadrophenia’.  Although after watching this film, two tracks from a different album come to mind: ‘Won’t Get Fooled Again’ and ‘Baba O’Riley’.
reviews.author: Jeff Mitchell

reviews.text: While I had fun with this film, I was disappointed. That being said, the movie is worth it just for Jonathan Majors.
reviews.author: Josie Meléndez

reviews.text: It's "Ant-Man" if it was "Star Wars" written by one of the "Rick and Morty" writers during an off day.
reviews.author: Josh Davis

reviews.text: One of the best MCU films in recent history because it doesn’t take itself so seriously. It delivers fun, light-hearted, and sometimes juvenile humor all the while delivering weighty plotlines and exceptional performances.
reviews.author: Maggie Lovitt

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania feels less like it’s a small part of a bigger plan and more as if it’s being forced to work against its own interests to serve a grand design.
reviews.author: Michael Burgin

reviews.text: Quantumania feels like pulling a random comic book from a box and going along for the ride. It’s not pushing the form further or playing with genre, but it is a fun adventure with great characters.
reviews.author: Ryan Silberstein

reviews.text: I quite enjoyed the absolutely phantasmagorical action of “Quantumania,” but like “Iron Man 2,” it would work so much better if it didn’t feel like a simple buffer before we get to the more urgent affairs with the Avengers.
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: When all was said and done, I walked away feeling unsatisfied...If not for a dedicated and highly professional cast, it’s possible this film may have gotten lost inside the relentless cogs of the MCU machine.
reviews.author: Johnny Gayzmonic

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania doesn’t feel like an Ant-Man movie, but there’s still plenty of fun to be had.
reviews.author: Collin Garbarino

reviews.text: The problem isn’t so much that the quantum realm looks unreal; it’s more that it looks unrealized, unfinished. Digital doodles.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania wants to psych you up about the launch of "Phase Five" of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, a corporate entity that's now 15 years old and starting to look a little winded.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: After viewing the latest rendition of the “Ant-Man” series, “Ant Man and the Wasp: Quantamania” starring the familiarly jovial Paul Rudd, I felt compelled to write my review as a letter to you both as well as director Peyton Reed.
reviews.author: Pamela Powell

reviews.text: Despite being an example of why a movie shouldn’t be shot almost entirely in The Volume, every time Jonathan Majors steps on screen as Kang, Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania is an epic tale to astonish and a monumental chapter in the Multiverse Saga.
reviews.author: Josh Wilding

reviews.text: The once playful runt of the Marvel litter has come down with a case of bloated excess and despite likable Paul Rudd as Ant-Man and a pow villain in Jonathan Majors, the third time is not the charm for a sequel that ignores its own rule -- less is more.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: As someone who is growing increasingly tired of the Marvel Studios formula, with all the same beats and story structure over and over, I found some solace in escaping into the Quantum Realm this time...
reviews.author: Alex Billington

reviews.text: Excellent performances from Majors, Pfeiffer and Rudd aside, this third instalment certainly feels destined to be in service of the larger cogs of the MCU rather than a worthy story in its own right.
reviews.author: Nicola Austin

reviews.text: Formulaic and forgettable, Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania is a dud.
reviews.author: Kshitij Rawat

reviews.text: At best, the Ant-Man entries should really be about 90 minutes long, have more humor and less kitchen sink being thrown at me.
reviews.author: Robin Clifford

reviews.text: Though it has moments of levity, most of its (blessedly short-ish) runtime merely sets up upcoming Avengers extravaganzas.
reviews.author: Peter Tabakis

reviews.text: While the tone of this goofy entry is all over the place, it does introduce Jonathan Majors as the menacing super villain Kang the Conqueror…and he nails it.
reviews.author: Russ Simmons

reviews.text: Whatever you may think of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, the ability to tell a good story with amazing special effects and spectacular costumes is first and foremost an essential part of the process.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text:
ANT-MAN AND THE WASP: QUANTUMANIA is a showcase for visual effects and that’s about it.
This looks like another franchise that has worn out its welcome.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: Major’s is a wonderful addition to the MCU and one hopes that they continue to flush out his character.
reviews.author: Kathia Woods

reviews.text: The title says it all because the story is more about the place than about what happens there.  There is just so much detail here, with the endless settings and characters so overwhelming that they make it hard to keep track of what is going on.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: The third Ant-Man installment certainly has some winning elements ... but it feels like it’s doing too much while trying to tackle something far too big.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: Too much going on, and not in a positive way. The barrier between the live actors and “I wonder how much digital tech it took to create the world” is very thin, and the STAR WARS wannabe plot and atmosphere was formulaic and uninspiring. I'm shrinking!
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: The third entry in the Ant-Man saga scales up the franchise’s appealing blend of sci-fi, comedy, and superhero spectacle.
reviews.author: André Hereford

reviews.text: Quantumania is a mid-tier MCU film, with decent enough battle sequences and some nifty visuals, but we’re here mostly for the popcorn-movie enjoyment of watching Paul Rudd et al., do their thing, and once again, the little guy and gang come through.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Ant-man and the Wasp: Quantumania is nowhere near as good as it needs to be to usher in a new phase of the MCU.
reviews.author: Britany Murphy

reviews.text: ... everything that's interesting about this movie is a variation of something we've already seen. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: Although it’s rarely more than another Marvel programmer, it’ll keep your attention for two hours.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: Majors is all might and menace.
reviews.author: Dana Barbuto

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is fast-food when audiences demanded a five-course meal.
reviews.author: Alan Ng

reviews.text: The whole thing suggests a spinoff of the Star Wars cantina sequence. It's weird fun most of the time.
reviews.author: James Verniere

reviews.text: Kang remains more myth than menace and, save for a few dorky gags and sweet father-daughter moments, it's an easily missable movie.
reviews.author: Josh Saunders

reviews.text: Introduces a handful of fun ideas, but they are all executed in that special, bland way that can only be created in a green box in Georgia by underpaid effects workers.
reviews.author: Dan Scully

reviews.text: It takes an impressive amount of ineptitude to plonk seasoned pros such as Douglas, Pfeiffer and Murray around a table and produce little more than awkward groans as Murray wheels out his “wacky lothario” schtick.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: What novelty exists here threatens to be swallowed by the ever-escalating stakes that were missing in the last two Ant-Man films, which were blissfully scaled smaller than their Avengers counterparts. Still, Rudd is charming and Majors riveting.
reviews.author: Christopher Llewellyn Reed

reviews.text: Rudd’s charisma brings a lightness of touch, and he provides some genuinely funny moments in the film. Majors brings the secret sauce as a great cartoon villain, but the talky script and messy action scenes suck away much of the fun.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: For those who recall the warnings He Who Remains gave in Loki (or even simply take a look at the titles the MCU has slated for the next year), it becomes quite clear how the film will end even before it begins.
reviews.author: Razmig Bedirian

reviews.text: Ultimately one of Marvel’s dullest and most unnecessary movies to date.
reviews.author: Emily Zemler

reviews.text: Marvel today is an amusement park, expanding, building new rides and attractions, trying, flailing and failing to recapture the magic of the past decade.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: ... despite having excellent ingredients, this great adventure ends up repeating the franchise's go-to instruction manual in a surprisingly bland way. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ricardo Rosado

reviews.text: By putting an Avengers-level threat into an Ant-Man film, the charm is gone, and all we’re left with is an emotionally empty barrage of special effects with less of the humor and joy that allowed these movies to shine in the first place.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: [Majors] is so quietly charismatic that, no matter how many civilizations Kang destroys, you kinda want him to win.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: Is superhero-osity finally exceeding its shelf life at the movies? I know, I know, that sounds ridiculous, but think of how ridiculous a similar question about westerns would have sounded, circa 1955.
reviews.author: Mark Feeney

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is the weakest entry point to begin a new phase of the MCU.
reviews.author: Eric Marchen

reviews.text: The future of the MCU is as uncertain as ever, but “Quantumania” has the train back up on the tracks and (hopefully) headed in the right direction.
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: ... this new adventure isn't as fun as the previous ones, it works only as by-the-book entertainment with more muscles than brains. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Marcelo Stiletano

reviews.text: Quantumania goes big, but it never forgets that Ant-Man is our guy.
reviews.author: Richard Whittaker

reviews.text: As is too often the case in the franchise realm, far less attention has been paid to the story. None of what transpires is surprising, which puts the burden on the actors.
reviews.author: Manohla Dargis

reviews.text: In the case of the third Ant-Man movie, bigger does mean better, but not without a few growing pains.
reviews.author: Don Kaye

reviews.text: There's action, humor, good lines, great special effects, and a most welcomed lightheartedness. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: If this is what we can expect from the future of the MCU, you can find me in the timeline where I stop following along.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: This wacky, terribly uneven, and often nonsensical movie places Phase 5 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe in peril. But in a way, this limp adventure leaves plenty of room to grow.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: "Quantumania" is, essentially, a two hour post-credits scene that left me totally uninterested in "Kang", his conquering, and whatever his legacy is or will be. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mario Alegre

reviews.text: The fun comes with Pfeiffer and the nonsense physics, the bubblegum vibe and Rudd’s fail-safe deadpan. The blockbuster fight scenes that were once every Marvel film’s centerpiece are throwaway. That much makes this an odd entry to the studio’s world...
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: And suddenly, I'm interested again in where the MCU is headed.
reviews.author: Tom Santilli

reviews.text: Director Peyton Reed stuffs the Quantum Realm with so much razzle-dazzle special effects, super powers, and bells and whistles that some of the characters and the story get lost.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: It is ... becoming increasingly difficult to appreciate these movies as individual pieces of media and narrative.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: I don’t care much for this movie. I had more fun helping others figure out the Kang conundrum than what actually happened on screen.
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: Ant-Man knows superheroes are a little ridiculous, and that even when your rescuing an entire tiny realm, it’s best to keep a sense of proportion.
reviews.author: Noah Berlatsky

reviews.text: The movie winds up being confusing (a sin) and dull (a bigger sin.)
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: The only part of Quantumania that is memorable is Majors who, without spoiling, will likely have more of a role in future films to come. One just hopes they're better than this one.
reviews.author: Chase Hutchinson

reviews.text:
Enthusiastic but unnecessary 
(with standout performances by Jonathan Majors and Michelle Pfeiffer).
reviews.author: Sherin Nicole

reviews.text: The Ant-Man films are always funny, but Marvel often feels it's necessary to throw in random forced jokes during the most serious moments, which nearly kills the third act. However, Jonathan Majors as Kang steals the show saving the film from disaster.
reviews.author: Brandon Avery

reviews.text: After the mixed reviews of the last few Marvel films, Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania looks set to continue the trend with the cast, especially Majors, stopping this from being a complete bore.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: The hordes of visual-effects artists whose names roll by in the infinity credits are the veritable auteurs of the film, with no overarching sensibility to guide them.
reviews.author: Richard Brody

reviews.text: Despite its flaws, Quantumania brings that traditional Marvel comic book flavor, along with deeper sci-fi weirdness, and is an overall satisfying experience.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Harris

reviews.text: [Peyton Reed] does an adequate job mixing the wacky silliness of [Jeff] Loveness’ script with a surprisingly hefty amount of a dark and serious tone this time around.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania feels like it's trying to be a Marvel movie. The jokes are played up too much. Not everything needs to be funny.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: Trying to be many things; a movie about family, an explosive start to Phase 5 and the arrival of its great villain, it achieves little of all that, because its tone varies too widely between dense, weird and messy. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Rivera Rubio

reviews.text: When QUANTUMANIA is crackling, it’s an oddball delight full of well-timed physical schtick, crazy world-building, and a game cast.
reviews.author: Jeff York

reviews.text: I will never unsee MODOK.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors as Kang was great -- [he] made the film entirely. I just wish the film he was in as a whole was better.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: Director Peyton Reed, who helmed the first two films, returns with a steady hand, and by now he knows the actors and the tone necessary to create compelling entertainment.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: To introduce Kang, really, is all Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania exists to do. In and of itself, it's a boring story devoid of meaningful stakes.
reviews.author: Jack King

reviews.text: This movie wants to give Scott more dramatic weight, but the thematic heaviness doesn’t suit the series or director Peyton Reed. The series was always better when it was funny, and despite Rudd’s best efforts, the comedy largely falls flat.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: ... lacks any hint of humor and no one seems interested in naturally performing the overwritten dialogues. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ezequiel Boetti

reviews.text: If we're going down the family-action-adventure road, I'll take Spy Kids over Quantumania any day.
reviews.author: Rachel Ho

reviews.text: A story so threadbare that it might have been written on a napkin, gussied up with a cascade of CGI effects that are splashy but rather ugly and exhausting.... If “Quantumania” is what Phase 5 is all about, perhaps Phase 5 should be phased out.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Humble MCU franchise spreads its wings, delivers big-time villain, thrills.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: These days, the world’s largest entertainment franchise is capable only of churning out advertisements for itself.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: As depicted here, Scott's entire personality, the whole of his character, is defined thus: "I love my daughter Cassie. Where is Cassie? What have you done with Cassie?"
reviews.author: Glen Weldon

reviews.text: The film accomplishes the feat of staying true to the goofiness of the previous Ant-Man films while still providing lots of great action and moving the overall story forward.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: Quantumania offers conventional fare (humor, family, and adventure) without taking any risks. It's simplistic and leaves aside the commitment to dig deeper failing to reach the stature of Doctor Strange or Spiderman. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Adrián Monserrat

reviews.text: Everything besides the introduction of Kang feels perfunctory, and an MCU entry (this is No. 31, if you're keeping score) has never felt so rudderless.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: It’s all entertaining enough, but Quantumania seems like an in-between enterprise, another chess move in the superhero series.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: After a promising first act that featured some relatable family conflict, the film falls apart by dividing our characters up in a contrived and inconsequential realm that had absent thrills and jokes that didn’t land.
reviews.author: Jason Escamilla

reviews.text: The Quantum Realm offers dazzling eye candy, but the novelty does not last. And the lack of freshness continues with a threadbare plot that tries to distract from the fact this film exists mainly to introduce a new Marvel movie phase.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: There's so much to sift through and occasionally like: a visually inspired subatomic set piece, bits of the roiling family tension among actors who are much better than their scripts. But there's nowhere to hide from the MCU's accelerating sprawl.
reviews.author: John Wenzel

reviews.text: Come for the scenery, and settle in for the next two hours trying to make sense of it. There’s no guarantee that you’ll love it, but what’s the quantum realm without a little uncertainty?
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: Marvel’s mini-hero is back in a movie that’s all scale, no fun.
reviews.author: Olly Richards

reviews.text: Despite some flaws, “Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania” is a joy ride. Because it does not take itself too seriously, you won’t either, which is the best way to experience this latest Marvel adventure.
reviews.author: Bob Bloom

reviews.text: ... "Quantumania" is a stellar time. ... some truly trippy sequences, some genuine excitement, and the characteristic laughs the "Ant-Man" films offer, and "Quantumania" is a strong start to Phase 5.
reviews.author: Douglas Davidson

reviews.text: Michelle Pfeiffer and Jonathan Majors really shine despite a frustratingly uneven script
reviews.author: Joe Passmore

reviews.text: Though visually impressive, this latest entry in the Marvel Cinematic Universe lacks narrative heft and coherence, leaving audiences dazzled yet underwhelmed.
reviews.author: John Kirk

reviews.text: It's not actively awful in any kind of meaningful way, because it's not remarkable enough to be that. Instead, it's a filler episode in the TV-ification of the MCU. It's fine if you miss it, because the next episode / movie will catch you up on it.
reviews.author: Brian Lloyd

reviews.text: The post-Endgame MCU continues to be a slog.
reviews.author: Jake Cole

reviews.text: This supersized, noisy and sometimes chaotic superhero adventure won’t be for everyone—particularly those who like their movies smaller, quieter, a bit more subtle and with less blowout spectacle, and fewer ants.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

reviews.text: Visually, the film is messy and flat; the CGI is shockingly poor and the action looks muddled. At least Quantumania has one of the best casts in a Marvel film.
reviews.author: Maria Lattila

reviews.text: A perfectly enjoyable, perfectly disposable post-content popcorn seller...essentially an animated film where the cast performed most of their roles in front of green screens... a good film to chew gum to.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: Delivers (however disjointedly) on "B-lister in over his head" cosmic adventure romp despite obvious post-Pandemic schedule-retooling into a big franchise place-setter; buoyed by a scene-stealing heavy turn from Johnathan Majors
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: Ant-Man and The Wasp: Quantumania has to be the most inert, lifeless film in the MCU yet.
reviews.author: Alan Cerny

reviews.text: This new Ant-Man outing truly lives up to its title. The manic multi-coloured world makes it feel like you’ve just stepped in the Star Wars cantina, while weird and wonderful creatures fill the screen.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: 'Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania' is certainly likable. It has laughs, astonishing visuals, and a terrifying villain. But it also has some little… bugs. There are just a few niggling flaws that bite at you and refuse to let go.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: While there's a kooky, psychedelic feel that echoes Star Wars and Guardians of the Galaxy, it falls under the weight of its own ambition and loses sight of what made its two predecessors so breezily enjoyable.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: Ant-Man is being asked to kick off Phase 5 of the wayward universe, a challenge he rises to meet.
reviews.author: Emily Wheeler

reviews.text: “Ant-Man” isn’t an example of bad comedy. It’s bad drama, bad science fiction, and a waste of everyone in it, including Evangeline Lily and Michael Douglas.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: A well-acted film with some elements that work, but that in general, doesn't quite come together; and that by trying to do a lot, it loses all the charm that was so present in its two predecessors. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: Quantumania may not be everything I wanted it to be, but from beginning to end this was a film that touched my heart, made me laugh, and dazzled my senses.
reviews.author: Richard Propes

reviews.text: Ironic that, after all the millions of dollars spent on computer generated pizzaz, the best special effects come from two of the real life stars, serving up some real life acting.
reviews.author: Joanna Langfield

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania starts Phase 5 off with a flop as a dull story and questionable execution causes the film to be a wildly worthless miss.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: This is a winning progression for Ant-Man and a wonderfully enjoyable blockbuster.
reviews.author: Grant Watson

reviews.text: Buried deep deep deep down in Quantumania is the heart of what a good Ant-Man movie could be, but it doesn't find it too often.
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: Quantumania feels less the start of a new phase of Marvel films than a tired retread of adventures we’ve already been on.
reviews.author: Derek Smith

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a chaotic, woefully unfunny mess that has forgotten why its hero was such fun. The thrill isn't just gone, it's been buried beneath a swarm of plot contrivances and truly hideous CGI.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Rudd and Majors try to lift up the superhero sequel, but it struggles with non-comedic storytelling and weirdly choppy editing.
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: If it were a meal, it would have magnificent plating and the fanciest sauce, but cut into it, and deep down it’s just a Big Mac underneath.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: It features a slew of talented actors doing their very best to treat the extremely silly movie as though it were Serious And Actually Meant Something.
reviews.author: Peter Martin

reviews.text: ...enough oogly landscapes and googly creatures to power two Star Wars pictures and half a Dune.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: Quantumania throws every can of paint in the garage at the screen while struggling with tone and convincing character dynamics. Jonathan Majors is an absolute beast as Kang the Conqueror. The MCU's Phase Five starts on uneven footing.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: … a very “mid” effort and Marvel better pull their finger out if they want these films to start feeling like must-see events again.
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: while the film is laden with a new purpose and a new world that marks this one something like the extended Lang family visits Disney’s “Strange World” by way of “Star Wars,” it is more entertaining than its predecessor
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: A big, dumb blockbuster that can't decide whether it's a crazy comedy or a gritty drama. A huge contrast between tone and narrative leaves this one feeling far too uneven... Tired of being continuously introduced to the Multiverse. Time to get on with it.
reviews.author: Dave Lee

reviews.text: Jonathan Majors should be referred to as “the defibrillator” because his intense performance gives the film desperately needed life. But the film is still unsatisfying, emotionally thin, and inconsequential
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: Funny, heartfelt, and exciting, and the villain is a worthy foe. Pfieffer and Majors shine. Most of the jokes work – with some falling flat – and perhaps there are a few minor visual effects that are less effective, but the weirdness made it work.
reviews.author: JimmyO

reviews.text: I have to confess I am getting quite sick of the sorcerer-style flashy and fiery effects so many of these comic book movies revel in. Mix it up next time, guys.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: If weird’s your thing, welcome to Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: I prefer my Ant-Man movies smaller than whatever this was
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: The story is in service of the larger Marvel engine, an increasingly creaky machine that nevertheless keeps grinding away, dropping superstar performers into CGI glop because the show simply must go on.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: Mostly it exists as connective tissue between different eras of the MCU, displaying embarrassingly little interest in its own main characters.
reviews.author: Gavia Baker-Whitelaw

reviews.text: If Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a portent of the franchise’s future, Marvel is in real trouble.
reviews.author: Clint Worthington

reviews.text: Majors is an absolute force with the stillness he brings to Kang. There’s a menacing quality bubbling under the service...
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: Quantumania is a lot of fun and is the most sci-fi heavy movie in the MCU. Felt like a blend of Marvel and Star Wars and Strange World. The world is gorgeous to see on screen. Majors is captivating as Kang.
reviews.author: Wendy Lee Szany

reviews.text: Quantumania is somehow heavy without feeling substantial, almost desperate in its dourness. Even scattered with occasional wisecracks, it makes Eternals feel positively breezy by comparison.
reviews.author: David Fear

reviews.text: An ultra generic and aggressively mediocre film that is intermittently elevated by the charm and charisma of its cast. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: Way too much of the film feels like they took the story they wanted to tell and then amped it up to be “bigger.” I actually loved many of the ideas, for places and characters… but it was all just too much, distracting from the core story.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: The third installment is the busiest movie of this Marvel trilogy with tons of distracting CGI environments.  Thankfully Paul Rudd carries the movie as the heart of the story but Michelle Pfeiffer and Jonathan Majors steal the show.
reviews.author: Lupe Rodriguez Haas

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania works on one key level, establishing Kang the Conqueror as a truly formidable and worthy villain. Yet with its plunge into inner space, "Ant-Man" comes up short in almost every other way that matters.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: Visually dazzling, but overstuffed, meandering, clunky and tonally uneven.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: Majors is certainly chilling and captivating, but Kang seems like a mismatched foe for a standalone Ant-Man film and the result is a Quantumania that is trying to be too many things.
reviews.author: Lindsey Bahr

reviews.text: Quantumania, as a whole, is a solid third movie in Scott’s franchise and a nod to relationships and science, and brings us a fresh take on his daughter, Cassie Lang.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: If it weren’t for Jonathan Major’s performance as Kang, this movie would be a complete fail.
reviews.author: Emmanuel Noisette

reviews.text: The humor is inconsistent, the visuals, while weird and partially engaging, are ugly, and if not for Paul Rudd’s amicable charm and the one, two punch of Johnathan Majors as Kang the Conqueror, the MCU would be in desperate need of some oxygen.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: What a chore this so-called entertainment is!
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: Peyton Reed and screenwriter Jeff Loveness seem to have gotten the tone just right this time around.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: As a movie to properly foist Kang the Conqueror onto the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania succeeds and then some. As a movie for Ant-Man, the Wasp, and their family of size-changing heroes? It’s only just fine.
reviews.author: Kyle Anderson

reviews.text: Quantumania starts Phase V off with a mixed bag, sporting a tour-de-force villain in Kang, who is smothered by a VFX mess, a sluggish plot and way too many painfully weird characters.
reviews.author: Lee McCoy

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania hits right in the center of recent Marvel content. It’s adventurous and energetic.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: For a franchise in need of refreshment, it’s anything but a quantum leap.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Just as readers will likely get lost in its gobbledygook subtitle, so too does Rudd get swallowed up by the consuming CGI insanity of his latest comic book extravaganza.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: Viewers old enough to understand even rudimentary narratives deserve better than a handful of scattered laughs and a great deal of visual unpleasantness.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumani” is a wild ride that will be more to some tastes than others.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: I didn’t hate it, I didn’t love it, it was kind of middle of the road for me.
reviews.author: Achara Kirk

reviews.text: Overall for me it was a visual spectacle, but... I was slightly underwhelmed about things.
reviews.author: Jaby Koay

reviews.text: Quantumania is proof, if we still needed it, that bigger isn't always better. In growing to typical Marvel size, it shrinks away the fun.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: Quantumania starts out on a messy note. The story and VFX are all over the place until Kang enters the picture. His haunting presence allows the film to find focus and become more entertaining. The third act is much better, and the humor mostly works.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: Quantumania ultimately serves neither Ant-Man nor Kang by pitting them against each other, going for big and small at the same time.
reviews.author: Susana Polo

reviews.text: Quantunmania is colorful, original, and different, and corrects the mistakes that Marvel has made during these three years of experimentation. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Randy Meeks

reviews.text: Marvel's mini-hero swaps charm for epic: bad call. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yago García

reviews.text: It's a quantum mess. It's bad enough that it recycles tired clichés of Marvel movies. This uneven superhero movie also rips off 1977's Star Wars in many ways. Jonathan Majors' standout performance can’t save this substandard spectacle.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: Though the stakes feel lackluster, and Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania trudges along at times rather than galloping at a clip, Marvel’s goodwill might make the film worthwhile.
reviews.author: DarkSkyLady

reviews.text: Feels unsure of its own journey, losing its personality in a sea of overt CGI and poorly-executed humour that, sadly, cheapens whatever genuine wit Jeff Loveness‘s script manages to occasionally muster.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: It's a wealth of visual chaos that hopes to distract from the absolutely nonsensical ideas.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: A bit of severity does an Ant-Man good, with “Quantumania” the best of the trilogy, at least when it focuses on the multiverse doomsday scenario and not wackiness.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: It's like something a kid threw together for a science fair, hoping that sheer charm would compensate for not having any actual science content. Too bad that, for all its amusing jokes, the world onscreen mostly looks like a Marvel screen-saver.
reviews.author: Matt Zoller Seitz

reviews.text: The best entry of the trilogy. Higher stakes, dangers and repercussions within the trippy Quantum Realm and for the rest of the MCU. Jonathan Majors is fantastic as Kang, the next big villain for Marvel. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Some really great stuff here - especially in the first half - from Rudd, Pfeiffer & Majors. But then the film totally falls apart, crushed under the weight of being asked to do too much for the franchise. It did make me want to buy Ant-Man's book...
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: Where the film falters, Jonathan Majors is there to lift it up with a genuinely fantastic performance as Kang. The next great Marvel villain has arrived, and somehow surpasses the hype.
reviews.author: Ron Seoul-Oh

reviews.text: Now 31 films and five phases deep into the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), and we’ve seemingly reached a new franchise low with Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania.
reviews.author: Andrew J. Salazar

reviews.text: While brimming with imagination thanks to environmental Quantum designs, Quantumania doesn't escape feeling like a layover between major franchise destinations.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is an unwieldy and monotonous repackaging of what came before.
reviews.author: Jeff Nelson

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is an epic sci-fi adventure that explores the family dynamics against the backdrop of a sci-fi war movie.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: Midway through, as everyone on screen was restating their interest in getting home again, I thought: Same!
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: Offers threats both immediate and long-range, making it satisfactory as both an individual movie and as a preview for what’s to come.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a solid start to the MCU's Phase 5, working well to serve Scott Lang's story and introduce the menacing Kang.
reviews.author: Molly Freeman

reviews.text: Quantumania’s tone is sure to be polarizing, but if you can surrender yourself to its bonkers A Bug’s Life-meets-Return of the Jedi antics, the two hours (already short for a Marvel film) will fly by.
reviews.author: Matthew Huff

reviews.text: In “Quantumania,” sprightly pacing and lighthearted humor have succumbed to the turgid seriousness that plagues so much of the comic book canon.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: Both a dispiriting reminder that the MCU has abandoned wit and that even the most clever and idiosyncratic of filmmakers can be steamrolled by the unstoppable obligations of corporate storytelling.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz

reviews.text: Watching the third Ant-Man film is sort of like being on a Marvel-themed acid trip that’s actually pretty fun until it comes to a confusingly abrupt halt.
reviews.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

reviews.text: Even as Ant-Man sizes up impressively and Kang makes an outsized entrance proper, Quantumania reminds us there’s value in sweating the small stuff.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: Strictly on its own terms, “Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania” isn’t much.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: If you can ignore the convoluted plot – not, sadly, a rarity in the increasingly complex Marvel Cinematic Universe – you’ll have a blast with these characters.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: While Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a fun ride at times and by no means the worst MCU film, it also lacks the key element that elevates the best entries in the franchise.
reviews.author: Brandon Zachary

reviews.text: Marvel, with all their resources, have made a film set in a universe where time and space are not as we know them, yet have ended up with something that looks surreal, but feels shackled. Mind-bending it is not. But that doesn’t mean it’s not fun.
reviews.author: Alex Godfrey

reviews.text: This Ant-Man is clever enough to be fun, and wise enough not overstay its welcome. Who better understands the benefits, after all, of keeping it small?
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: Maybe the pictures should get small again; it might be the only way to save an MCU that seems dangerously close to getting too big to do anything but fail.
reviews.author: Kate Erbland

reviews.text: A disappointing adventure that loses it heart amidst mountains of multiversal exposition while failing to set up an interesting path forward for the franchise.
reviews.author: Evan Dossey

reviews.text: It certainly feels like replacing the low-stakes caper energy of the Ant-Man movies with tedious, wheel-spinning teases of what comes next is a grave miscalculation.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Zhang

reviews.text: Prepare to be slammed by special effects, hammered by an ear-battering soundtrack. Oh, and you’ll be left mewling for mercy after an onslaught of Truly Bad Dialogue.
reviews.author: Soren Andersen

reviews.text: How is something that is supposed to be small become something that is way, way, way too much?
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: “Quantumania” is fun, as well as bedazzling, relentless and numbing, then fun again just when you think you’ve had enough; all of that gets mashed together.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: In terms of scale and importance, Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is an enormous step forward, but there are some growing pains that come along with it.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: While it’s not surprising that [Majors'] imposing physicality perfectly suits his iconic villainous character, he also invests his performance with such an arrestingly quiet stillness and ambivalence that you’re on edge every moment he’s onscreen.
reviews.author: Frank Scheck

reviews.text: This is my kind of family-focused relationship light drama and fun, and it helps that the wider picture of where the MCU is heading finally starts to come into focus. QUANTUMANIA is an ant-astic return to form for Marvel after a few lackluster entries.
reviews.author: Aaron White

reviews.text: Paul Rudd and Evangeline Lilly might be first-billed on the poster, but this is undeniably the Jonathan Majors show – did Marvel just find its next great villain?
reviews.author: Alex Flood

reviews.text: Instead of bringing comic books to life, Quantumania turns live-action into comic books. Visual effects are a given with fantastic superhero movies, but when everything surrounding the actors is animated, nothing is tangible.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: All in all – particularly when balanced against the weightiness of Majors’s performance – Quantumania nicely hits the mark: it’s goofy, but goofy to just the right degree.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: Does Kang bang? Why yes, he does. Majors brings the same emotionally intense it-boy energy of Adam Driver in The Force Awakens.
reviews.author: Ellen E Jones

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania is a mess of a film that fails to capture the things that made the first two films great and chooses instead to spend its entire two-hour runtime setting up for later payoffs.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: Peyton Reed wants to make a 'Star Wars' film which is great for him because that’s clearly where his ambitions lie, but it’s bad for the “Ant-Man” franchise because the strengths of that series— its humor, its modesty, its small-scale humanity—are missing
reviews.author: Rodrigo Perez

reviews.text: Quantumania might be key to kicking off the big arcs to come in the MCU Phase 5, but it doesn’t forget to have a good time.
reviews.author: Liz Shannon Miller

reviews.text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania has just enough heart, humor, and excellent performances to make up for its more underdeveloped aspects.
reviews.author: Joshua Yehl

reviews.text: Quantumania is a promising, but shaky start for Phase 5 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, it's just a shame it comes at the sake of the little guy.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: Majors thankfully rights the ship every time he pops up with his deliciously disconcerting presence.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: Sorry to Raid on your parade, “Ant-Man” fans, but the third chapter is a pile of dirt.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: This chapter continually hobbles itself, churning out a hackneyed, exposition-heavy story that’s a nothing-burger – a feeble, forgettable and frustrating product.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: A sensory overload of a movie that has its charms but ultimately leaves you feeling empty inside.
reviews.author: Joey Morona

reviews.text: Quantumania works best when it’s focused on being a silly self-contained sci-fi movie and not the laying the foundation for the next couple of years of movies and Disney+ shows.
reviews.author: Sean Mulvihill

reviews.text: Tonally this film is different from the other films.  A bit uneven, it feels like Jeff Loveness’ script wasn’t sure what genre this movie wanted to be. The first two Ant-Man films were straightforward with their comedy and pretty on the nose about it.
reviews.author: Jamie Broadnax
